article.title: Bill_Bryson
article.paragraph: William McGuire"Bill"Bryson,Order of the British EmpireOBE,Royal Society#FellowsFRS(IPAc-enˈbraɪsən; born December 8, 1951) is a best-selling American author of humorous books on travel, as well as books on the English language and science. Born in the United States, he was a resident of Britain for most of his adult life before returning to America in 1995. In 2003 Bryson and his wife and four children moved back to Britain, living in the old rectory ofWramplingham,Norfolk. He served as the chancellor ofDurham Universityfrom 2005 to 2011.Bill Bryson ProfileatDurham UniversityIMDb name0117445Guardian topicbooks/data/author/bill-brysonNYTtopicpeople/b/bill_bryson

Bryson came to prominence in the United Kingdom with the publication ofNotes from a Small Island(1995), an exploration of Britain, and its accompanying television series. He received widespread recognition again with the publication ofA Short History of Nearly Everything(2003), a book widely acclaimed for its accessible communication of science.
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Bryson was born inDes Moines, Iowa, the son of Agnes Mary (ne McGuire) and sports journalistBill Bryson, Sr.("I come from Des Moines, Iowa. Somebody had to."  Bill Bryson, "The Lost Continent"). His mother was of Irish descent.The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid, p121.He had an older brother,Michael BrysonMichael(19422012), and a sister, Mary Jane Elizabeth. In 2006 Bryson publishedThe Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid, a humorous account of his childhood years in Des Moines.

Bryson attendedDrake Universityfor two years before dropping out in 1972, deciding instead to backpack around Europe for four months. He returned to Europe the following year with a high-school friend, the pseudonymous Stephen Katz. Some of his experiences from this trip were relived as flashbacks inNeither Here Nor There: Travels in Europe, which documents a similar journey Bryson made twenty years later.
article.heading: Move to the United Kingdom
article.paragraph: File:BillBryson02.JPGthumbBryson speaking in New York, 2013Bryson first visited Britain in 1973 during a tour of Europehttp://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/mar/14/bill-bryson-books-interview-follow-up-notes-from-a-small-islandand decided to stay after landing a job working in a psychiatric hospital  the now-defunctHolloway SanatoriuminVirginia Water,Surrey. He met a nurse there named Cynthia Billen, whom he married. They moved to Bryson's hometown of Des Moines, Iowa in 1975 so that Bryson could complete his college degree at Drake University. In 1977 they settled in Britain, where they remained until 1995.cite newsFamous Iowans: Bill Bryson firstLongdenDes Moines Registerhttp://data.desmoinesregister.com/famous-iowans/bill-bryson

Eventually living inNorth Yorkshireand mainly working as ajournalist, Bryson became chief copy editor of the business section ofThe Timesand then deputy national news editor of the business section ofThe Independent. He left journalism in 1987, three years after the birth of his third child. Living inKirkby Malham, North Yorkshire, Bryson started writing independently and in 1990 their fourth child, Samuel, was born.

Although able to apply forBritish nationality lawBritish citizenship, Bryson said in 2010 that he had declined a citizenship test, declaring himself "too cowardly" to take it.cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2010/may/29/bill-bryson-england-citizenship-testLondonThe GuardianPatrickBarkhamBill Bryson: I’ll cheer for England, but I won’t risk citizenship test2010-05-29However, in 2014, he said that he was preparing to take the test.http://www.nursinginpractice.com/article/interview-bill-brysonIn the prologue to his 2015 book "The Road to Little Dribbling" he describes his experiences taking and passing the British citizenship exam. He subsequently applied, and was accepted for British citizenship, but retained his American citizenship so holds dual nationality.
article.heading: Writings
article.paragraph: In 1995 Bryson returned to the United States to live inHanover, New Hampshire, for some years. While there he wrote acolumn (periodical)columnfor a British newspaper for several years, reflecting on humorous aspects of his repatriation in America. These columns were selected and adapted to become his bookNotes from a Big CountryI'm a Stranger Here Myself, alternatively titledNotes from a Big Countryin Britain, Canada, and Australia. During his time in the United States, Bryson decided to walk theAppalachian Trailwith his friend Stephen Katz (a pseudonym), about which he wrote the bookA Walk in the Woods (book)A Walk in the Woods. In the 2015 film adaptation ofA Walk in the Woods (film)A Walk in the Woods, Bryson is portrayed byAcademy AwardsAcademy AwardwinnerRobert Redfordand Katz is portrayed byNick Nolte(Bryson is portrayed as being much older than he was at the time of his actual walk).cite webNotes from a huge landmassElizabethGleickMay 30, 1999New York Timeshttps://www.nytimes.com/books/99/05/30/reviews/990530.30gleickt.html

Also in 2003, in conjunction withWorld Book Day, British voters chose Bryson's bookNotes from a Small Islandas that which best sums up British identity and the state of the nation.cite newsBryson tops 'England' poll2003-03-06[[BBC News]]http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/2824715.stm2008-08-05In the same year, he was appointed a Commissioner forEnglish Heritage.

In 2004 Bryson won the prestigiousRoyal Society Prizes for Science BooksAventis Prizefor best general science book withA Short History of Nearly Everything.Cite newsMichellePauliBryson wins Descartes prize for his guide to scienceThe Guardian2005-12-07http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2005/dec/07/scienceprizes.billbrysonLondonThis 500-pagepopular sciencework explores not only the histories and current statuses of the sciences, but also reveals their humble and often humorous beginnings. Although one "top scientist" is alleged to have jokingly described the book as "annoyingly free of mistakes",Cite newsBill Bryson: The accidental chancellorThe Guardian2005-11-15http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/profile/story/0,11109,1642405,00.htmlLondonJohnCrace2010-04-26http://web.archive.org/web/20100525015756/http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/profile/story/0,11109,1642405,00.html25 May 2010noBryson himself makes no such claim and a list of some reported errors in the book is available online.cite webhttp://errata.wikidot.com/0767908171Errata and corrigenda: "A Short History of Nearly Everything" by Bill BrysonIn 2005, the book won the EUDescartes Prizefor science communication.

In November 2006, Bryson interviewed the then British prime minister,Tony Blair, on the state of science and education.citationhttp://number10.gov.uk/output/Page10500.aspPM in conversation with Bill Bryson2009-04-102006-11-292006-11-30[http://number10.gov.uk The official site of the Prime Minister’s Office]
In January 2007, Bryson was the Schwartz Visiting Fellow at thePomfret SchoolinConnecticut.Pomfret Swartz Fellows

In May 2007, he became the president of theCampaign to Protect Rural England.cite newsBryson to head litterbug campaign2007-05-02[[BBC News]]http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/6614295.stm2008-08-05cite webhttp://www.cpre.org.uk/news/view/382Contact Us - Campaign to Protect Rural EnglandHis first area of focus in this role was the establishment of an anti-littering campaign across England. He discussed the future of the countryside withRichard Mabey,Sue Clifford,Nicholas Crane, andRichard Girlingat CPRE's Volunteer Conference in November 2007.

Bryson has also written two popular works on the history of the English language The Mother TongueandMade in America (book)Made in America  and, more recently, an update of his guide to usage,Bryson's Dictionary of Troublesome Words(published in its first edition asThe Penguin Dictionary of Troublesome Wordsin 1983).
article.heading: Awards and honours

link.part: Bryson in the regalia of Chancellor ofDurham University, withDurham Cathedralin the background

article.paragraph: In 2005 Bryson was appointedchancellor (education)chancellorofDurham University,succeeding the latePeter UstinovSir Peter Ustinov, and became more active with student activities than is common for holders of that post, even appearing in a Durham student film and promotinglitter picksin the city.cite newsBill Bryson Litter Pick2008-03-01[[durham21]]http://www.durham21.co.uk/2008/03/bill-bryson-litter-pick2011-09-17He had praised Durham as "a perfect little city" inNotes from a Small Island. He has also been awarded honorary degrees by numerous universities, includingBournemouth University(April 2002) and theOpen University.Bill Bryson visits his utopia(May 7, 2002),The Independent.

In 2005 Bryson received the President's Award from theRoyal Society of Chemistryfor advancing the cause of the chemical sciences. In the same year, Bryson and the RSC jointly created the Bill Bryson prize, an annual award to encourage science writing in schools."Westminster setting for Bill Bryson award", 31 October 2005, accessed 21 November 2010.

In 2006Frank Cownie, the mayor of Des Moines, awarded Bryson theFreedom of the Citykey to the cityand announced that 21 October 2006 would be known as "Bill Bryson, The Thunderbolt Kid, Day".The City of Des MoinesWayback20080625025709http://www.randomhouse.com/features/billbryson/news/CityofDesMoinesProclamation.pdfProclamation of October 21, 2006 as "The Thunderbird Kid" Day(archived fromthe originalon 2008-06-25)

On 13 December 2006, Bryson was awarded an honoraryOrder of the British EmpireOBEfor his contribution to literature.cite newsBill Bryson made an honorary OBE 2006-12-13[[BBC News]]http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6176363.stm2008-08-05The following year, he was awarded theJames Joyce Awardby theLiterary and Historical Society (University College Dublin)Literary and Historical SocietyofUniversity College Dublin.
In 2007 Bryson won theCINE#AwardsGolden Eagle Award.cite webhttp://historybooklet.com/bill-bryson-biographyBryson Start of Golden Period

In October 2010, it was announced that Bryson would be stepping down from the role ofchancellor (education)chancelloratDurham Universityat the end of 2011.cite newsBill Bryson stepping down as Chancellor2010-09-20[[Durham University]]http://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno2011-07-04

On 13 November 2012, Bryson was awarded an honorary doctorate fromKing's College London. According to King's site, the award was relating to: "Bill Bryson OBE: the UK's highest-selling author of non-fiction, acclaimed as a science communicator, historian and man of letters."cite newsBill Bryson receives honorary doctorate 2012-11-14[[King's College London]]2012-11-14File:BillBryson03.JPGthumb2013On 22 November 2012, Durham University officially renamed theDurham University LibraryMain Librarythe Bill Bryson Library for his outstanding contributions as the University's 11th Chancellor (200511).cite newsThe Main Library is being renamed 'The Bill Bryson Library'!2012-09-25[[Durham University]]https://www.dur.ac.uk/library/news/?itemno2012-11-27cite newsBill Bryson Library renaming event, Tuesday 27 November 20122012-11-22[[Durham University]]2012-11-27

Bryson was elected an HonoraryList of Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 2013Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) in 2013,cite webhttps://web.archive.org/web/20151005151051/https://royalsociety.org/people/bill-bryson-11156/2015-10-05https://royalsociety.org/people/bill-bryson-11156Mr Bill Bryson OBE FRS Honorary Fellow[[Royal Society]]Londonbiographical text reproduced here was originally published by the Royal Society under a creative commons licensebecoming the first non-Briton upon whom this honour has been conferred.cite newsNew Fellows 2013 2013-05-02[[Royal Society]]http://royalsociety.org/about-us/fellowship/new-fellows-2013/2012-05-03cite newsHonorary Fellows of the Royal Society2013-05-23[[Royal Society]]http://royalsociety.org/about-us/fellowship/honorary-fellows/2013-11-24His biography at the Society reads:centered pull quote<arg name="Bill Bryson is a popular author who is driven by a deep curiosity for the world we live in. Bill’s books and lectures demonstrate an abiding love for science and an appreciation for its social importance. His international bestseller, A Short History of Nearly Everything (2003), is widely acclaimed for its accessible communication of science and has since been adapted for children.
His belief in the importance of science in shaping our future — and the need to improve how we communicate the vitality and excitement that science provides — led Bill to set up the Bill Bryson Prize for Science Communication, in conjunction with the Royal Society of Chemistry. The competition engages students from around the world in explaining science to non-experts.
Bill has received numerous awards for his remarkable ability to communicate science with such passion and enthusiasm. For the Royal Society’s 350th anniversary, Bill edited Seeing Further: The Story of Science and the Royal Society (2010), enabling the Society to convey the excitement and relevance of its own history to a wide audience.<ref name">frs/>
